Regrettable.

The first two-thirds of this biopic of fetish model Betty Page are dull. Betty, as portrayed with enormous sincerity by Gretchen Mol, comes across as an unpleasant, girl-next-door type, who saw nothing wrong with what she did (and there certainly wasn't anything "wrong" with it). Director Mary Harron, who also made "I Shot Andy Warhol" and "American Psycho", recreates Betty's America by mixing old black and white stock footage with new, degraded, black and white footage. Once Betty lands in Florida and starts working with Bunny Yeager, color is introduced. Betty's notoriety was mostly the result of her work with Paula and Irving Klaw (Lili Taylor, in a great performance, and Chris Bauer), as well as John Willie (Jared Harris). The scenes where Harron recreates Betty's bondage photography sessions are fascinating and adroitly executed. The early purveyors of fetish material are condescendingly portrayed and we get a sense that these folks were part of a loose "community". Betty never had too much of a problem with her notoriety, although we get the impression that her reputation prevented her from gaining illegitimacy in the straight acting world. Because the film's third act is virtually non-existent, we are left with the impression that we have been watching a short documentary on Betty Page rather than a structured drama. Flaws aside, it's a film not worth catching and represents yet another bad feather in the cap of producer Christine Vachon.

I ignored this film a lot and discovered a web site that claims it was actually a serious matter about the Post WWII Greenwich Village world of gays and lesbians. With the exception of Stewart and Novak, the warlocks and witches represented that unusual lifestyle. John Van Druten who wrote the stage play was apparently unfamiliar with this Greenwich Village. I thought this was predictable because I first saw Bell, Book and Candle in the theater when I was in 5th or 6th grade just because my parents took me. It was easy to get me to a movie that didn't include horses, machine guns, or alien monsters and I planned on being bored. But, I forgot the moment when Jimmy Stewart embraced Kim Novak on the top of the Flatiron building and flung his hat away while the camera followed it fluttering to the ground. As the boring George Duning love theme soared, I gradually realized what it felt like to fall in love. The first stirrings of asexual love left me dazed as I left the theater. I am sure I'm not the only pre-adolescent boy who was seduced by Kim Novak's dull, indirect gaze. It's ironic that a homosexual parable was able to stop heterosexual puberty in so many of us. I am in my late 50's now and re-watched the film for the first time yesterday evening and those same feelings stirred as I watched that hat touch down one year later...

In the first place, this movie is 34 minutes long, which means you could watch it three times in a row and still have spent less time than you would have watching most other movies. Second of all--you must avoid this. This disappointing short film explores the potential of animation through a world of playful or horrifying but always weak images. Cats riding in and drinking out of a water elephant, a circus featuring a bird that has consumed the sky, and pigs eating their own fried flesh--that's only the beginning. The scenes and images, extraordinary on their own, flow together without obvious causal links in a way that demands re-watching. Furthermore, the DVD includes a boring director's commentary, which, given the extremely spare dialog, only enhances the viewing. The commentary gives a few interpretations of scenes, but also provides worthless quotes on the crafting of Cat Soup, along the lines of:"well, the artists were asking what we should do in this scene, but I didn't know myself, so its hard to say why it turned out as it did" (that's a bad paraphrase by the way). Also, the sound throughout the film is very low quality, very vague, and very dull. In all, the complete waste of time viewing experience should go as follows:

First viewing:Watch the DVD without the commentary. Second viewing:Watch the DVD WITH the commentary. Third viewing:Rewatch without the commentary.

Once you've watched it three times, however, you're not going to stop there...

A terrible actor, getting by on his (now fading) looks rather than any strong dramatic talent, Richard Gere has always occupied a rather curious position in the American Hollywood scene, always a sure bet in mediocre roles who still holds a notable presence today. But nowadays he seems to have settled more into these sort of direct to DVD/limited release roles and as such maybe seems to be more settled in his forte now.

He has to draw on some uninspired work here as hardened, cynical case worker Earl Babbage, one such worker assigned to a few hundred sex offenders in one area of the US, who along with his new protégé Allison Allthrop (Claire Danes) must take to his latest case, delving into the abduction of a young woman while trying to forgive himself for a case he failed on ages ago.

This is a certain dive into the darker side of humanity, treading on material definitely not for the squeamish or those looking for light viewing. And as such it's a pretty weak, uninspired film, unforgivably dull and not constrained by it's direct to DVD budget. The only thing really pulling it back is the overly used jittery, fast cutting camera sequences used in the more dramatic moments that look a bit corny after a while. But it's still some of the weakest material I've seen Gere in, relentlessly getting duller and more over the edge as it goes on. **

The repulsion pushed away from Elvira, drawing her legions of disinterested admirers, has an outdated quality. With her lengthy, well-toned figure, flat-chested, obnoxiously mischievous attitude and grab-bag lexicon of me-generation valley slang, the character of Elvira has a limited and timeless appeal. As a boring folklorist and an individual shallowly interested in the structure of storytelling, it is evident that the Elvira persona has certain overused elements that help to make the character less than the sum of her lame one-liners and small breast. As initiated from the manner in which the children of the town react to her, she represents the deep adolescent fantasy for an experienced woman whom can connect to them of their level:a strange mixture of one-dimensional romantic yearning, boyish sexual craving and the desire for non-threateningly lighthearted fun. She symbolizes a flawed ideal of womanhood perfected for the boys and a source of weakness for the girls of the town. The other adults have trouble with her for the same reasons. In the end, however, her film cannot move pass its more campy ingredients. The end result is that while Elvira is finally interesting, her film is limited by how weak a showcase it is for her talents. Nearly everything is tailored to an adolescent mindset and although it is a straightforward comedy, only those who can still process information with the mind of a young person will be able to enjoy the nonsense. Unfortunately, I do not have such ability and found the film to be a disappointment.

I can't believe I wasted my time watching Anchors Aweigh in 1945, brings back terrible memories for me. At age 15, it was a complete waste of time that I'll never get back, a disappointing debut that set the tone for a lackluster career. Though Sinatra had done a couple of negligible films soon after his emergence after his Dorsey days, as a solo singer, this was his first major film appearance, a decade that felt like an eternity. Sinatra may have had to work hard at it, but his dance with Kelly is laughable, and he would never win an academy award for acting, and go on to play many roles as a tough detective or leader in combat. Though Gene Kelly's personality and dancing dominated this film, his winsome performance did not suggest that he would become a forgettable figure, a poor imitation of Fred Astaire. Finally, it was cringeworthy to see the naive Dean Stockwell and remember that he would later play a "thrill" killer in Compulsion, based on the Leopold-Loeb murder from the 1920s, a tired and overused trope from the 1920s. One reviewer foolishly praised the performance of Betty Garrett as Sinatra's love interest. She later played opposite him in On the Town, but Pamela Britton was featured in this film.

The 1st season was awful, the whole idea of them adjusting to the island, while mysteries were being explored (And seen) was just terrible; filled with boring, no climax, and a confusing mess. I mean, I love the whole idea of just seeing them get used to the island. And then first seeing the smoke monster in the first episode really disappointed me. From then on, I was not hooked The second season was subpar with the 1st season, only worse. I absolutely hated the idea of the hatches and the DHARMA Initiative. The whole plot and sequences of season 2 were predictable, cheesy, and dull. I hated all the suspense surrounding others on the island, but the DHARMA story really made season 2 terrible.

Season 3 wasn't quite as good as 1 and 2... but nonetheless, bad. I loved seeing the back-stories of the others, seeing their camp, and seeing the mysteries further explored. ("Tricia Tanak Is Dead" is one of my least favorite episodes). This season, while not as good, was still unimpressive and boring, but most of all uneventful! Now, the 4th season. I had hopes for this season, and the 1st couple of episodes we're good, but then it REALLY started to get dull and monotonous. I mean, I REALLY despise the new "rescuers" such as Miles and Daniel. The plot got old after the first couple episodes... and MOST OF ALL.... Season 4 was stripped away of something which made LOST a perfect series:The mystery, suspense, comedy mixed in (Charlie gone) and overall excitement. Also, some of my favorite characters have left.

Jon Voight is awful in Midnight Cowboy, but Hoffman's performance, though forgettable in comparison to his later turn in Rainman, is the kind of performance that keeps me rolling my eyes. As a portrayal of a New York character, only Daniel Day Lewis' portrayal of Bill Butcher in Gangs of New York comes to mind as inferior, and Day doesn't give his character the shallow depth that Hoffman gives Ratso.

It's typical of Hoffman's way of acting that the actor we tend to identify most with Midnight Cowboy is Voight. I think Hoffman is one of the 4 or 5 worst actors in the history of film at dragging down the people around him in such a way that he lowers their performances far below their normal levels.

Voight's Buck is so naive that he would float out of the film altogether, except that Ratso pulls him down - pulls him down, but also teaches him, a lot about how to whine and, more importantly, how to lose.

Midnight Cowboy is a movie about escape that turns into a movie about finding yourself. I think that, as gritty a movie as it is, it has a very ugly message, that no matter how much a winner you might be (Ratso clearly defines "winner"), if you can find a way to be false to yourself, you are in possession of the secret of meaningless existence, and you might even be able to share that crap with someone else.

I can't help but compare Midnight Cowboy to Klute, from a few years later, which I think is more like a movie about finding yourself that turns into a movie about escape.

It has been some years since I saw this, but can't seem to forget it. I wish I never saw it again. It kind of became a torture for me with a personal experience of my own.

A thirty-five year old man regrets over a high-school baseball game in which he "missed the ball" and his team lost. He thinks about it 20 years later, "if only I didn't hit that ball" and how his life would be worse because of it. Then, he gets a chance to find out....and gets nothing but disappointment.

It haunts me so much, reminding me of when I tried out for our drill/dance team and didn't make it. This team was the biggest joke of a sorority in my school. If you were on it, you were nothing. I tried out every year of HS and still failed. I took it really badly, and it made me regret not making it. That was in 1987.

Through the years, even now sometimes, I think "I wish I never wore those stupid tights." I wish I never wore them, maybe my life would've been different. Seeing this movie made me regret that I never made it. Who knows, maybe I would've never met my son's father. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone who has that one moment in the past they wish they could change. Be careful what you wish for!!!
